newsitem.title: USA: UAL sees slight rise in Q4 load factor.
newsitem.headline: UAL sees slight rise in Q4 load factor.

text.p: United Airlines parent UAL Corp said Tuesday it expects to show a slight increase in its passenger load factor in the fourth quarter compared with a year ago.
"Fourth quarter bookings look very good," John Edwardson, president, told reporters in a teleconference.
He added that fuel costs are still an issue for United, but some relief is expected.
Jet fuel costs for the fourth quarter are expected to decline to about $0.78 a gallon from $0.80 early in the quarter, he said.
Edwardson said UAL generated cash flow of $923 million in the third quarter, which was partially used to pre-pay debt and also to purchase aircraft.
The company said it retired $63 million in principal amount of long-term debt in the third quarter, which was part of its continuing efforts to achieve an investment-grade credt rating.

UAL also said that this debt retirement, combined with similar initiatives completed in the first and second quarters, will save more than $100 million annually in gross interest expense and dividends.

"A continuing theme at the company is to move towards an investment grade credit rating," Edwardson said. "We continue to hope that this will happen within about an 18-month period. And we have made great progress (toward this goal) and are actually ahead of schedule."
Also in the the third quarter, UAL took a pretax charge of $30 million, or $19 million after tax, to write-down the value of aircraft seats.
Edwardson said improving aircraft seats is part of United's efforts to improve customer satisfaction. "Our customers tell us they're (seats) uncomfortable," he said.
Another customer issue, he added, is on-time performance. United currently rates fourth among the 10 major airlines in on-time performance, Edwardson said.
"We'll be working hard to improve on-time performance this year," he said.
He added that, for the first time, executive compensation for about 600 people will be linked to on-time performance.
He later said it's unclear at this time how compensation and on-time performance will be linked.
